title: What should I and shouldn't I do to increase my voice quality for singing? - Quora

response.answer_text: I will try and point out the things that worked for me: Do this in the given order during the morning. If your time is finished say doing step 1 itself then don’t go beyond. Repeat again the same next day until you can do it in lesser time. (Set your tanpura to G# so that your ‘Sa’ is G#) Ujjayi Pranayam - This is the best pranayam that cleans the throat and vocal chord, improves lung capacity for singing in addition to bringing in positive thinking, freshness and high level of concentration. Its better to do this first in the morning before beginning ‘riyaaz’. Do this initially for about 90 mins and later bringing it down to 30 mins.Humming from the nostrils: Its best to start off by humming the ‘Sa’ through the nostrils while keeping the mouth closed while playing ‘tanpura’ in the background. Don’t exhale too fast while doing this. Do it slowly and try to create a constant clear sound. Do this initially for about 45 mins and later bring it down to 15 mins.Chanting Om: After the humming its best to chant ‘Om’ along with the tanpura. Do this for 30 mins initially and then bring it down to 10 mins.Sa ka riyaaz: This is the best riyaaz for the entire stretch of vocal chords. Play the tanpura in the background and sing the ‘Sa’ with the mouth open. Intake maximum possible breath and then don’t forcefully exhale, just let the breath go out on its own while singing ‘Sa’. Try to maintain a constant pitch while exhaling the last breath out of the lungs. Ensure that the environment is not very cold and dry.Swara riyaaz: Start with ‘Sa’ then go to ‘Ni’ - one swara down, then ‘Sa’ again and then ‘Re’. Ensure you can distinctly sing the three notes clearly without distortion. Then add one more note down and up so there are total 5 notes to sing. Repeat these five until there is a distinct sound for all of them. Add one more not down and up and you have now 7 notes to sing, repeat the same and then add one more so you will have 9 notes to sing. Don’t go beyond 9, just ensure you do this with clarity and you are done.Sa Sa - Ni - Sa - Re - Sa Sa - Ni - Dha - Ni - Sa - Re - Ga - Re - Sa Sa - Ni - Dha - Pa - Dha - Ni - Sa - Re - Ga - Ma - Ga - Re - Sa Sa - Ni - Dha - Pa - Ma - Pa - Dha - Ni - Sa - Re - Ga - Ma - Pa - Ma - Ga - Re - Sa What you shouldn’t do is Forcefully singing a note that you can’t singSinging high pitched songs when you know that you haven’t developed that range.Shouting while singing to project your voiceSinging on a full stomachSinging Karaoke songs without first practicing on the harmonium

You see, voice quality, (as the natural quality of vocal cords and resonators) is not the most cricual part in singing.  Here, I'd use a metaphor for explanation: there are bigger and smaller hands; there are hands with short fingers, and some have very long and thin fingers. But this doesn't really affect what you write and where you put commas. It can influence your manner of writing, the handscript a bit (however, it's highly dependent on your habits), but each manner is ok indeed if it's readable. It can be more or less readable, or it can take more or less space... You can sing different styles and a diversity of genres if it fits to your voice. If it doesn't, why would you consider changing the nature of your hand with a "surgery"? The same is true for singing: improving your voice is like improving your hand (I deliberately not touch the manners, but only the nature of the apparatus). Well, here are some suggestions: Don't smoke. Do never try.No alcohol. At least before singing. No beer at all. No soda water. No stark lemon, no seeds in big quantities.Talk less. Read more. No yelling, shouting, overindulgence partying, etc.Pay attention to your posture (try Alexander technique). Collapsed rib cage is one of the reasons for poor breathing.Study right breating.If you are a guy, ladies should be kept at a distance, at least before important events, for three days at least.If you make sports, great! But if you are tired while singing, your result would be the same as if you had an injured arm. No fanaticism in sports, please.Keep yourself in good mood. Sleep well.

I am a classical singer and do not have a very strong voice. I, however have a good voice throw and can sing boldly at higher pitches. My problem is the base or lower octaves. What I do are1)Get up early in the morning and practice the lower octaves. The stronger your base voice gets , the better will be your clarity. Your voice will be fresh and basic at dawn. Hence you can have a better reach in the lower octaves. 2) It's also important that you do this regularly.3) If you are susceptible to whether changes then make sure you take proper care of your throat and voice. If your voice is good enough then you will still be able to pull through a musical performance like some of my friends do and they can do this because of regular practice .4) There's this ayurvedic medicine called "kantil" which most of musicians take to maintain voice texture. I tried it for some months and it was useful. It can get rid of soar throat for a while. Don'ts1) Dont eat/ drink cold stuffs often. Stick to food stuffs that are of moderate temperature.2) Dont overstrain your voice. If you cannot reach the higher octaves try to slowly expand your octave. Don't try to make it to the highest note at one go. Do it step by step.3) Shouting at top of your voice often, singing at pitches that are not suitable to you can stagnate your voice texture and clarity. Your voice improvement will not be significant. 4)  Find the pitch that is suitable for your voice. Improve your voice in that pitch. On an average a person can sing in 2.5 octaves. The maximum is 3 octaves.Hope you find this informative. These are the things I have been doing for a while and its really helping me to get a better tone.

The first word is S L O W L Y!  If you are looking to improve for your own enjoyment, then start with warming up your voice--doing scales slowly from the bottom of your range to the top and then the reverse.  These should be done quietly and smoothly.  Then practice vowel sounds in different keys. Drink plenty of water between exercises.  Then sing what you wish slowly working your way up to loud (but not bellowing). If you are hoping for a career, especially in classical music and you are at least in your late teens, find a teacher.  He/she will determine your vocal range and help you develop it.   A teacher will always have you warm up and correct any errors I made in the advice above. Whether classical or folk, the most important thing is that you enjoy what you are doing.  Music is a wonderful thing! Good luck

Breathing in the right way is very important for good voice quality. Most of the people use very small portion of their breathing capacity for singing. You can find various videos on breathing techniques on YouTube which can help you in singing. This will improve your tonality in the low range as well while exerting enough force on high notes. As mentioned by others, Practice is very important. But you need to decide your style of singing and then practice in that particular direction. There are countless singing styles and genres and practicing for every genre is different. You can get into the details as per your liking. But breathing, definitely is at the base of them all.

Gargle with warm salt solution.This will clean your throat for the exhaling voices. And also increase your talent in high pitch songs. 2. Avoid yelling. Yelling and screaming and going “hihoohooohahahaha” will damage your voice box. And will make you sound like dying goat or something. And you definitely don't won't that. 3. Practise octaves every now and then. Practise makes a man perfect. As the saying goes. 4. Avoid oily & spicy food. Spicy and oily stuffs will make microscopic linings in the inner walls of the throat, this will help your exhaling voice to escape and will make the singing sound like…….i don't know….fart?

The biggest mistake is singing too loudly early in the morning. do lil humming first before singing and sing softly till 10-11 am. afterwards you can sing high notes.2. don’t eat fried food and pickle before singing.3. do not eat or drink too cold or hot items4. don’t sing at high tempo(speed). when you are just learning to sing a new song, sing slowly giving full time on every note (thehraav se gaao).5. try to sing those songs that match your voice range. (if u have heavy voice then sing songs of mohit chauhan and arijit sing and if you have soft voice then sing songs of atif aslam, enrique etc.).6. drink a lot of water to keep your throat hydrated.7. watch youtube tutorials on indian classical music (siddharth slathia).

In answering these sorts of questions, my first hesitation is telling someone to learn on his or her own. A teacher of voice is an essential tool for development of one's vocal abilities. In any endeavor to better oneself with something as fine as your voice, professional help is strongly advised so as to prevent learning anything incorrectly and potentially causing irreparable damage. I would recommend finding someone who has a degree in voice studies and has experience in teaching new voices. If you experience anything you have questions about, always seek professional help.

Riyaz, Riyaz and Riyaz (Practise)......and as Ankur said, try not to skip it even for a day.......also while practising, just try to make sure that you are using different regions for creating the resonance, that is, when singing a lowest notes, the area around the navel and around should vibrate and then on singing a bit higher, the vibration should shift towards the chest and so on, until towards your face. You may keep your hand for the check. This is to ensure that you do not solely use the area around your neck as that won't help better the tonal quality of your voice.

Do’s 1 - Practice ( Always prefer the type of songs your voice match with) 2 - Sing it from the soul as no one is listening to you (makes you more comfortable and your voice becomes more confident) Do not 1 - Do not try to copy any one (Be original always) 2 - Do not try to scream, try to keep it low.

The best way is solfège. Solfège are the "do-re-mi"s. When you learn solfège, you become adept at hearing the note before you sing it because it strengths your auditory skills. This has a huge affect on your confidence which will result in improving your tone. Solfège is taking risks in singing because it gives you the edge of understanding the music at a deeper level. That is the first thing I would do to improve! Happy d-r-m-ing!

PRACTISE!!! That’s all you can do. Sing as much as you can. Riyaz and let your Vocal Chords free. FACT : All humans have same vocal chords. Singing isn’t a skill one has since birth; you have to develop it.

Do continues Riyaz- PractiseDon't skip your practice in between and don't do it intermittently.. There are lots of tricks based upon the kind of singing you want to do. You may contact me for the same. :)

Do you want to work on your voice or is it to work on your singing skills? To get a better tone out of your voice.. It is mainly how you control your breath .. So record yourself onto your mobile..try to sound different every time... See which one gets your ears... Try to recreate that tone you set for yourself.. As for honing your singing skills... There are multitudes of online tutorials that take you through exercises

Not knowing what you want to improve or what needs improving, in general, I would say:  -learn how to breathe to support your voice properly -learn to sing a vocal line legato with each note strung together like a pearl -learn how to use your (facial) mask to concentrate the sound so it has focus and carries.

To increase your voice quality you need to train your voice,you shouldn’t take in cold things, you shouldn’t eat food containing too much oil. Also jogging helps by the air we breath in and out whiles running help us to release more phlegms .
Practice. Record yourself, listen to it and practice more. Consider a vocal coach. Listen to what he/she tells you. Practice some more. Oh, did I mention that you need to practice?
